Award.AwardTitle: Denmark Strait Overflow Water: A New Paradigm for the Origin of the Deep Western Boundary Current
Award.AbstractNarration:
The North Atlantic Deep Western Boundary Current constitutes the lower limb of the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (MOC), and, as such, is a crucial component of the Earth's climate system. Dense water formed north of the Greenland-Scotland Ridge returns southward by flowing through the gaps in the ridge and descending the continental slope as overflow plumes. The largest of these is the Denmark Strait Overflow Water (DSOW) plume which passes between Greenland and Iceland and forms the densest component of the MOC. Presently, it is believed that the primary source of the DSOW is the East Greenland Current, a southward-flowing current along the continental slope of Greenland. Recently, however, direct shipboard velocity measurements and detailed hydrographic information in the vicinity of Denmark Strait suggest that a substantial fraction of the overflow water originates from the Iceland side of the strait, in addition to the Greenland side. In particular, a newly discovered narrow current, called the Northwest Icelandic Jet, appears to transport overflow water directly into Denmark Strait from the Iceland Sea. If this is the case, it means that the ventilation process forming a large part of the Deep Western Boundary Current is not what the oceanographic community presently envisions. In order to understand how global warming and the consequent enhanced surface freshwater fluxes will impact the MOC, it is imperative to have an accurate understanding of where the DSOW emanates from and the processes that form it.

This project will use moored velocity and moored hydrographic time series to determine and quantify the sources of the DSOW, while simultaneously measuring the main northward pathway of heat and salt to the southern Iceland Sea. This is made possible through collaborations with scientists at the Marine Research Institute (MRI) in Reykjavik, Iceland, who will contribute both moorings and ship time to the project. The principal investigator will deploy an array of profiling moorings across the Northwest Icelandic Jet to establish its existence, and quantify its structure, transport, and dynamics. At the same time MRI will maintain moorings in the East Greenland Current, the overflow plume at Denmark Strait, and in the Icelandic Irminger Current. In concert with the observations a modeling study will be conducted to understand the origin of the Northwest Icelandic Jet and the water mass transformation and overturning that drives it. The expected outcome is that a new paradigm will emerge regarding the origin of the Deep Western Boundary Current, which will modify how the community views the links between climatic forcing and the sources of the DSOW.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed project will enhance the current understanding of the water mass transformation, currents, and pathways that lead to the formation of the North Atlantic Deep Western Boundary Current.

Broader Impacts: By clarifying the origin of the DSOW, the results of the project will shed light on the links between the atmospheric forcing and the North Atlantic MOC, which in turn impacts the global ocean circulation and Earth?s climate. This will allow to better anticipate how the MOC will respond to global warming. The U.S. fieldwork is closely coordinated with the activities of MRI as well as with the European climate program THOR (Thermohaline Overturning Circulation at Risk). MRI has committed significant resources to the project in the way of instrumentation and ship time. The proposed outreach involves participation in the project by school children from four different countries (including Greenland), and a graduate student will be educated by the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the fundamental current systems in the global ocean is the
Meridional Overturning Circulation or MOC, which helps regulate
Earth's climate. In the Atlantic, warm surface water flows poleward
representing the upper limb of the MOC. After it crosses the ridge
between Greenland and Scotland into the Nordic Seas, the water loses
heat and is transformed into cold, dense water. This dense water then
returns southward at depth, and the largest part of it flows through
the Denmark Strait, located between Greenland and Iceland.

Previous thinking contended that all of the dense water approached
Denmark Strait in a boundary current known as the East Greenland
Current. However, the recent discovery of the North Icelandic Jet --
an equatorward-flowing current transporting dense water along the
north slope of Iceland -- called this into question. The overall goals
of our research project were to identify the sources of dense water
that feed Denmark Strait, quantify the circulation and transport of
the dense water, and determine how the North Icelandic Jet is
formed. Our program was part of a collaboration between institutions
from four countries: Iceland, Norway, the Netherlands, and the
US. Together we deployed a year-long mooring array spanning the
northern part of Denmark Strait, and carried out a series of
cruises. In addition to this, we ran numerical simulations to
investigate the causes of the circulation.

Our project revealed that the equatorward transport of the North
Icelandic Jet (NIJ) roughly balances the poleward transport of the
warm and salty Atlantic water through Denmark Strait, and that both
currents "disappear" near the northeast corner of Iceland. A numerical
model suggests that these two currents represent the upper and lower
limbs of a local overturning circulation in the Iceland Sea, such that
the Atlantic water is converted to dense water by air-sea heat loss
during winter. In particular, the warm water is shed into the interior
Iceland Sea as small rotating lenses of water (see the figure). The
lenses become cold, and the dense water eventually returns towards the
Iceland slope where it sinks and feeds the NIJ.  This is a completely
different paradigm than the warm-to-cold conversion that occurs in the
East Greenland Current (EGC) around the perimeter of the Nordic
Seas. It means that the response of the MOC to a warming climate may
be more complex than originally thought.

We also discovered that the EGC splits into two branches before
reaching Denmark Strait (see the figure). The inshore branch is called
the shelfbreak EGC and the offshore branch is called the separated
EGC. Modeling results indicate that the separated EGC forms due to the
unstable nature of the shelfbreak EGC.

Using data from our mooring array we quantified the transport of dense
water in each of the flow pathways feeding Denmark Strait. We found
that, in the mean, the shelfbreak EGC accounts for 42% of the total
transport, and the separated EGC and NIJ account for 30% and 28%,
respectively. Notably, while the total transport remains roughly
constant through the course of the year, there is significant
partitioning between the three branches. Using atmospheric data
together with our mooring records, we demonstrated that changes in the
wind largely dictate the relative amount of water carried by the NIJ
versus the two EGC branches.

We also assembled all of the historical shipboard measurements
collected in the vicinity of Denmark Strait over the past 25
years. This revealed that the NIJ water has become warmer and saltier
over time, and also that there are large year-to-year variations in
the salinity of the dense outflow.  These variations are in phase with
the salinity fluctuations of the inflowing Atlantic water. The reason
behind this was shown to be the temporal changes in the large-scale
wind and rainfall patterns in the northern Atlantic.  The historical
shipboard data, together with long-term mooring data from Denmark
Strait, also revealed that the flow of dense water through the strait
varies pronouncedly on a day-to-day basis. This in turn impacts the
behavior of the water far to the south of Denmark Strait in ways that
need further exploration.
